The defense and critique exchanges reinforced that, while the status quo and clinical inertia are powerful, the risk of a symbolic or political filing or rescheduling has genuinely increased, but not to the point of making a 'Yes' outcome likely. There is no new information from the group that would justify changing my probability, as all plausible tail-risk scenarios were already incorporated. Thus, I maintain my 30% probability.

Public Health Policy (RegulatoryScience).reasoning_for_revised_probability: After reviewing the group deliberation, I note a strong consensus among regulatory, clinical, and policy experts that the base rate for a qualifying event (NDA/EUA filing or DEA rescheduling) remains low, but is meaningfully elevated by recent political and administrative signals. Most forecasters place their probabilities in the 22-42% range, with the median clustered around 30-35%. Critiques of lower-probability estimates (e.g., 9%) convincingly argue that the question's low bar for resolution (filing not approval, or DEA rescheduling) and the exceptional late-2025 political context make a symbolic or strategic filing plausible. However, the group also consistently emphasizes the stickiness of the status quo, lack of public signals of imminent filings, and the operational hurdles facing sponsors and the DEA. My original estimate (38%) is already near the high end of group consensus. The only strong argument for revision would be to align even more with the very highest estimate (42%), but on balance, I see the consensus as support for the upper end of the 30s, not for a significant upward revision. Therefore, I maintain my probability at 38%.

Public Health Policy (HealthTechnologyAs.reasoning_for_revised_probability: After reviewing the group deliberation, I observe that most expert forecasts cluster between 22% and 39%, with a strong consensus that the base rate is low but meaningfully elevated by the current political, regulatory, and advocacy environment. Several forecasters, especially those in Regulatory Affairs and Clinical Trial Management, emphasize that even symbolic or strategic filings or DEA rescheduling are plausible, but the lack of concrete signals of imminent action and the persistent operational inertia of US regulatory bodies remain significant counterweights. My initial forecast (42%) was at the very top of the group, and upon reflection, it may slightly overstate the tail risk given the remaining tight timelines and the absence of public indication of a near-term qualifying event. The group’s nuanced arguments—especially about how even under political pressure, filings or rescheduling actions typically require some bureaucratic preparation—suggest that while the window is open, it is not as wide as my initial forecast implied. I am revising my probability slightly downward to 38%, aligning more closely with the upper end of the group consensus while still reflecting the real, above-base-risk of a late-breaking action before year-end.

US Law and Regulation (FDAApprovalProces.reasoning_for_revised_probability: The group deliberation revealed that most expert forecasters assign a probability between 22% and 42%, with the modal range around 30-35%. The main arguments for a higher probability than my initial 12% are: (1) the unusually broad resolution criteria (filing or rescheduling is sufficient), (2) the exceptional political and regulatory pressure in late 2025, (3) explicit agency signals about expediting psychedelics, and (4) the real potential for symbolic or strategic filings and DEA actions, even absent NDA-ready data. My initial forecast placed heavy emphasis on the status quo and base rates, but I now recognize that I underweighted the genuine tail risk created by the current unique political environment and the possibility of a sponsor or administrator acting for policy signaling rather than strictly on data readiness. While I still view the status quo as dominant and see no public evidence of an imminent NDA/EUA filing or DEA rescheduling, the probability of a surprise next-step event before the end of 2025 is higher than my initial estimate.

The lower (sub-15%) estimates are consistently critiqued for underweighting the significance of the current political and regulatory environment, especially the increased risk of a symbolic NDA/EUA filing or DEA rescheduling action even without the usual evidentiary bar. The highest estimate (42%) is defensible from a health technology assessment perspective but may slightly overstate the probability given the absence of concrete evidence of imminent filings or rescheduling. question_details.title: Will the next step for the medical approval of psychedelics for mental health be taken in the US in 2025?
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2024-12-20 21:18:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/31134). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

In August of 2024, the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) [declined to approved MDMA as a treatment for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)](https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/fda-rejects-psychedelic-mdma-assisted-therapy-ptsd-rcna165531). Prior to the approval MDMA was [often touted as a potentially promising treatment](https://www.psychiatrist.com/news/mdma-assisted-therapy-may-be-the-next-frontier-in-ptsd-treatment/), but ultimately the drug [faced a number of concerns](https://www.vox.com/future-perfect/353752/mdma-fda-approval-hearing-lykos-blinding-misconduct-allegations) about its efficacy results that led to its denial.

Other psychedelic drugs [are in the midst of trials](https://psychedelicalpha.com/data/psychedelic-drug-development-tracker), but trials can often be lengthy and may not produce the necessary results in time for a submission in 2025. [Other possible pathways](https://ondrugs.substack.com/p/the-eua-psychedelics-backdoor-cracks) to psychedelic medical use could include an emergency use authorization (EUA) or federal rescheduling under the Controlled Substances Act.

***

This question belongs to Vox's Future Perfect Community page and 2025 forecasting tournament. [Learn more and compete for the $2,500 prize pool](https://www.metaculus.com/c/future-perfect/).

`{"format":"metac_closes_in_period","info":{"post_id":31134,"question_id":30860}}`
question_details.resolution_criteria:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if any of the following happens after December 31, 2024 before January 1, 2026:

* A New Drug Application (NDA) for the treatment of a mental disorder (as defined by the [Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Illnesses](https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/articles/24291-diagnostic-and-statistical-manual-dsm-5), the DSM-5) is filed to the FDA for a psychedelic.
* An application for an Emergency Use Authorization (EUA) for the treatment of a mental disorder (as defined by the DSM-5) is filed to the FDA for a psychedelic.
* The DEA reschedules any psychedelic under the U.S. Controlled Substances Act to a less restrictive schedule (e.g., from Schedule I to Schedule II).

For the purposes of this questions, a psychedelic is defined broadly and includes:

* psychedelic indolealkylamines(e.g. LSD, psilocybin, DMT)
* psychedelic phenylethylamines (e.g. mescaline, MDMA, the 2C series)
* arylcycloalkylamines with psychedelic or dissociative effects (e.g. PCP, ketamine)
* Salvinorin A

Cannabinoids (e.g. THC) are *not* considered psychedelics for the purposes of this question.
question_details.fine_print: The NDA or EUA application do not need to be accepted, simply filed.

**Jaguar Health Completes Meeting with FDA for Advice on Development Pathways to Advance Ongoing Crofelemer Trial for Potential Approval for Treatment of Pediatric Indication Microvillus Inclusion Disease (MVID)**
Jaguar Health, Inc. (NASDAQ:JAGX), through its family company Napo Pharmaceuticals, completed a Type C meeting with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) on October 2, 2025, to seek guidance on advancing its clinical development program for crofelemer powder for oral solution in treating microvillus inclusion disease (MVID), a rare pediatric disorder. The ongoing investigator-initiated proof-of-concept trial in the United Arab Emirates (UAE) demonstrated a 37% reduction in total parenteral support (PS), including a 30% reduction in total parenteral nutrition (TPN), following reinitiation of crofelemer dosing after a 12-week drug cessation period—exceeding the previously reported 27% PS reduction at 12 weeks. The FDA meeting was attended by members of Napo’s Scientific Advisory Board, including the principal investigator of the UAE trial. Pravin Chaturvedi, PhD, Chief Scientific Officer and Chair of the Scientific Advisory Board, stated that the FDA discussion was collaborative and indicated potential pathways to support approval, especially if the study is amended and deemed adequately controlled. Lisa Conte, CEO of Jaguar Health, emphasized gratitude for the FDA’s regulatory support and noted that orphan drug designations have been granted by both the FDA and the European Medicines Agency (EMA). The company plans to pursue regulatory discussions in the EU and Middle East/North Africa (MENA) regions to expand access globally. An abstract detailing partial results from the UAE trial has been accepted for presentation at the North American Society for Pediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology and Nutrition (NASPGHAN) Annual Meeting, November 5–8, 2025, in Chicago. Additionally, Jaguar is supporting two expanded access programs in the U.S. under FDA authorization to treat pediatric MVID patients with intestinal failure. MVID affects an estimated 100–200 patients worldwide and currently has no approved treatments, with a lethal natural history and significant comorbidities.

**Cellectar Biosciences Announces European Medicines Agency (EMA) Confirms Eligibility to File for Conditional Marketing Authorization (CMA) for Iopofosine I 131 as a Treatment for Refractory (post-BTKi) Waldenstrom Macroglobulinemia (WM) | Taiwan News | Oct. 6, 2025 19:00**
Cellectar Biosciences, Inc. (NASDAQ: CLRB) announced that the European Medicines Agency's (EMA) Scientific Advice Working Party (SAWP) has confirmed eligibility to file a Conditional Marketing Authorization (CMA) application for iopofosine I 131 as a treatment for refractory (post-BTKi) Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia (WM). The CMA submission is expected in early 2026, with potential European approval and commercial launch in 2027 across 30 EMA member countries. Iopofosine I 131, a first-in-class phospholipid ether-based radioconjugate monotherapy, has received PRIME designation from the EMA for WM patients with at least two prior lines of therapy. The CLOVER WaM Phase 2 study demonstrated an overall response rate (ORR) of 83.6% and a major response rate (MRR) of 58.2% (95% CI, 0.42 to 0.67), with data presented at the 66th Annual American Society of Hematology Conference in December 2024. The SAWP advised that the proposed patient population—post-BTKi refractory patients—meets eligibility criteria for CMA, though it did not assess the sufficiency of safety and efficacy data. The U.S. FDA has granted iopofosine I 131 Breakthrough Therapy, Fast Track, and Orphan Drug Designations. Cellectar plans to submit a New Drug Application (NDA) to the FDA under an accelerated approval pathway once a confirmatory trial is underway, though this depends on securing additional funding. The company emphasized the drug’s advantages: fixed dosing, 'off-the-shelf' supply, long-term isotope supply agreements, orphan drug pricing, and PRIME designation, positioning it as a strong candidate for global partnerships. The unmet medical need in WM is significant, with no FDA-approved treatments for patients progressing on BTKi therapy, and over 5,700 patients in the U.S. requiring third-line or greater therapy. The company's forward-looking statements include risks related to regulatory pathways, funding, and collaboration efforts.

Publish date: October 06, 2025 11:14 AM
Source:[Taiwan News](https://taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/6214488)

**Spanish Hospitals Validate Psychedelic Treatments for Chronic Depression, Anticipate Approval Within Two Years**
Spanish hospitals are validating the clinical use of psychedelic drugs—such as psilocybin (found in mushrooms) and 5-MeO-DMT (from ayahuasca)—to treat chronic, treatment-resistant depression, a condition affecting one-third of all depression cases. Clinical trials in Spain are in Phase 3 for psilocybin and Phase 2 for 5-MeO-DMT, with specialists predicting regulatory approval by the Ministry of Health 'no earlier than two years' from now. According to Eduard Vieta, head of psychiatry at Hospital Clínic de Barcelona, psychedelics produce rapid, significant improvements in depression, with some patients achieving full remission after just one or two doses—up to 87.5% in Phase 3 trials with 25 mg of psilocybin. These treatments are administered in hospitals under strict medical supervision. Maria Dueñas from Parc Sanitari Sant Joan de Déu confirmed the significant antidepressant effects of psilocybin in clinical trials. Other psychedelics like LSD and ayahuasca also show efficacy and safety. While no psychedelics are yet approved for prescription, experts believe they will bring a 'radical change' in depression treatment. The future of depression care is moving toward personalized medicine, integrating biological diagnosis, pharmacogenetics, and targeted therapies such as transcranial magnetic stimulation. Specialists like Víctor Pérez and Maria Portella emphasize the importance of individualized, biologically informed treatment. Claudi Camps, director of Mental Health and Addictions in Girona, stresses the need for a holistic approach, recognizing that depression arises from a combination of biological vulnerability, trauma, poverty, and psychosocial stressors. He notes that unresolved childhood trauma can resurface in adulthood, exacerbating depression—highlighting the importance of revisiting past experiences in therapy. Despite progress, chronic and treatment-resistant cases remain challenging, with relapses common after one to two years, though psychedelics and deep brain stimulation are improving outcomes.

The meeting included members of Napo Pharmaceuticals’ Scientific Advisory Board, including the principal investigator of an ongoing open-label investigator-initiated trial (IIT) in the United Arab Emirates (UAE). The company plans to pursue regulatory discussions in the EU and Middle East/North Africa (MENA) regions to bring crofelemer to patients globally. An abstract of the UAE trial’s partial results has been accepted for presentation at the North American Society for Pediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology and Nutrition (NASPGHAN) Annual Meeting, November 5–8, 2025, in Chicago. The United States congenital hyperinsulinism (CHI) treatment market is projected to grow at a high compound annual growth rate (CAGR) from 2023 to 2030, with significant developments in 2025 driving market momentum. Rezolute announced the completion of enrollment in its Phase 3 sunRIZE study for ersodetug, a treatment for CHI, with 62 participants and topline data expected in December 2025. Ltd, and Uno Healthcare. **Arcadia Medicine Announces FDA Clearance of IND Application for a Patented Form of MDMA**
Arcadia Medicine has announced that the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has cleared its Investigational New Drug (IND) application for AM-1002, a patented, non-racemic form of MDMA. The company plans to initiate a clinical trial for AM-1002 in patients with Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) in 2025. AM-1002 is engineered to selectively release serotonin and oxytocin—key neurotransmitters for therapeutic effect—while minimizing stimulant effects, neurotoxicity, hyperthermia, and cardiovascular risks. The compound also offers flexible dosing, enabling more precise and adaptable treatment regimens. Arcadia Medicine has raised $9.25 million from investors including Sam Altman, Fred Ehrsam, and Dylan Field, and holds a Composition of Matter patent for non-racemic MDMA, securing exclusive rights to this formulation. Nikita Obidin, founder and CEO, stated that the IND clearance reflects progress in developing a safer, more targeted version of MDMA. Sam Altman praised Arcadia’s work as 'an important step towards a potentially transformative psychiatric treatment,' while Fred Ehrsam expressed excitement over supporting a non-neurotoxic MDMA development. Arcadia is also advancing a broader pipeline, including AM-1004, a mildly entactogenic antidepressant, and AM-1006, a short-acting, subperceptual psychoactive compound for therapeutic use. The company’s mission is to scale safe mental health therapies globally, including potential at-home prescription use.

The SAWP advised that the proposed patient population—post-BTKi refractory patients—is acceptable for CMA, consistent with over 70% of patients in the CLOVER WaM trial. The U.S. FDA has granted iopofosine I 131 Breakthrough Therapy, Fast Track, and Orphan Drug Designations. A U.S. New Drug Application (NDA) is planned after confirmatory trial initiation, which is contingent on securing additional funding. The company emphasizes the drug’s potential for long-term response, fixed dosing, 'off-the-shelf' supply, and multiple isotope supply agreements, positioning it as a high-value opportunity for global partnerships. The unmet medical need in WM remains significant, with no FDA-approved treatment for BTKi-refractory patients and over 5,700 patients in the third-line or greater treatment category. **Psychodélicos: Czechs Authorize Psilocybin**
The Czech Republic has officially legalized the medicinal use of psilocybin, a decision announced in July by President Petr Pavel. The new law follows a model similar to Australia’s 2024 regulations, where MDMA and psilocybin are approved for treating post‑traumatic stress disorder and treatment‑resistant depression, respectively. Unlike Australia, the Czech law does not include MDMA and restricts psilocybin to synthetic preparations, whereas New Mexico in the United States has allowed the use of natural Psilocybe mushrooms. Only psychiatrists trained in psychotherapy may prescribe psychedelic substances in a clinical setting; general and public hospitals receive automatic authorization to offer the treatment, while other facilities will need special licensing.

The legislation also decriminalizes cannabis possession. In the United States, a broader biomedical regulation of psychedelic‑assisted psychotherapy (PAP) was expected but was rejected by the FDA in August of the previous year, denying a license for MDMA in post‑traumatic stress disorder from the company Lykos. The change in U.S. administration has opened the possibility of approval for psychedelic treatments, with figures such as Robert Kennedy Jr. and veterans, firefighters, and police officers advocating for their use.

In a September 11 article in *Psychoactives*, Czech lawyer Tereza Dlestikova critiques the new medical model, arguing that the reform remains incomplete without evidence‑based debate on non‑clinical uses of psychedelics. The Czech law contrasts sharply with U.S. state referendums, such as Oregon (2020) and Colorado (2022), which authorized licensed facilitators to run psilocybin sessions without medical prescription.

Key metrics and facts: • July 2025 – Czech law enacted by President Petr Pavel. • 2024 – Australia authorizes MDMA and psilocybin for PTSD and depression. • New Mexico – permits clinical use of natural Psilocybe mushrooms. • August 2024 – FDA rejects MDMA license for PTSD. • 2020 & 2022 – Oregon and Colorado approve psilocybin centers for non‑therapeutic facilitators.

The CRL was one of 89 rejection letters issued last week, and it cited several safety and efficacy concerns.  Lykos failed to provide data on adverse events that would help assess abuse potential, did not demonstrate that treatment effects lasted beyond the eight‑week assessment period after the last dose – a period the FDA says must show durable benefit for a chronic condition – and the study had high rates of prescreening failure and prior MDMA use, raising the possibility of selection bias.  The FDA therefore recommended a new clinical trial to address these gaps.  FDA Commissioner Marty Makary said the agency will promptly release new CRLs and approvals, redacted for trade secrets, to help developers understand the FDA’s reasoning. Rick Doblin, founder of the Multidisciplinary Association for Psychedelic Studies, praised the Trump administration for making the CRL public and noted that the FDA “moved the goalposts,” shifting its standards after the study was underway. **New Hope for Mental Health: Can Psychedelic Substances Be a Breakthrough?**
The European Commission is already taking action. Within the Horizon Europe program, it has funded the PsyPal study with 6.5 million euros, led by a consortium of 18 research centers and universities, with the University of Groninga as the lead. The researchers aim to verify the effectiveness of psilocybin treatment for various mental disorders: post-traumatic stress disorder, depression in patients with palliative care needs for severe diseases such as ALS or COPD. The study is generating high expectations. The question is: can psychedelic substances really be a new frontier in treating many mental illnesses? Commonly known as drugs, they are illegal and stigmatized, but in therapeutic doses and always associated with psychotherapy, they could be a breakthrough? The University of Trento, with the first Italian conference on the topic, promoted by the Department of Psychology and Cognitive Sciences, asked this question last year. The conference broke a taboo. Following the many clinical trials conducted abroad, which seem to demonstrate their effectiveness, a specific scientific society, Simepsi, was born in Italy about a year ago, led by psychiatrist Mauro D'Alonzo, which deals with training and research on psychedelic medicine. 'If the law passes also in the Senate, it will be the first EU country to introduce them in therapeutic protocols,' says Caterina Bartoli, a doctor and member of Simepsi. In Australia, psilocybin and MDMA are already approved and prescribable. The first is also authorized in New Zealand, while in Switzerland it is regularly used on request from psychiatrists after the green light from a specific commission. 'In reality, the use of these psychoactive substances has a millennial history,' says Tania Re, a psychotherapist and anthropologist who also works in Switzerland in collaboration with psychiatrists. 'It's a history linked to the culture of many indigenous communities and passed down orally from generation to generation. It's crucial to continue to investigate their safety and efficacy, the neurobiological mechanisms and the optimal procedures for a safe and replicable therapy.' 'There are many advanced studies, particularly in the United States and the United Kingdom - explains Bartoli - with a strong increase in scientific publications on the subject. In the US, the phase III of a study on the efficacy of MDMA in treating post-traumatic stress disorder has just been concluded, conducted by the scientific society Maps and the pharmaceutical company Lykos.' The Food and Drug Administration, the US regulatory agency, has asked for further data, although a 70% efficacy has already been demonstrated with just three administrations. In the UK, depression is the focus. In this field, the study by the pharmaceutical giant Compass Pathways, which has also reached phase III, is worth mentioning. The study on the treatment with psilocybin, which would validate the effectiveness of the psychedelic substance, compared to a traditional antidepressant, with a single administration, is being conducted under strict medical control, also to manage any potential side effects, such as headaches, nausea, and increased blood pressure. 'Effects that generally resolve within 24 hours,' continues Bartoli. In Italy, the only substance with psychedelic effects authorized is esketamine, a derivative of ketamine, commonly used in operating rooms. It is used by psychiatrists in the form of a nasal spray. In the US, it is used for treatment-resistant depression and suicidal ideation, while in Italy only for treatment-resistant depression. Since 2017, thanks to a ministerial decree, the use of psychedelic substances is allowed only in exceptional and compassionate cases. However, they are never prescribed. And there are no clinical trials involving Italian universities. 'On the one hand, there is still a lack of knowledge in the field among our doctors, on the other hand, the molecules with psychoactive effects are still perceived as recreational drugs, to get a high,' observes Bartoli. From here, the initiative of the Luca Coscioni association, which has launched an appeal to the government, signed by 170 doctors, researchers, and psychotherapists, to allow the use of these experimental treatments. An appeal accompanied by a signature collection, promoted together with Simepsi, to ask the European Commission to fund research on psychedelics. 'The resistances are not only of an ideological type: a part of the medical class remains anchored to traditional medicine based on psychopharmaceuticals,' says Marco Perduca, coordinator of all the activities of the association related to psychoactive substances.

summary:
Across all expert perspectives, there is broad agreement that the base rate for an NDA/EUA filing or DEA rescheduling for psychedelics for mental health in the US within a single year—especially in the months immediately following the August 2024 FDA rejection of MDMA for PTSD—is very low. The experts highlight that most major clinical programs (e.g., for psilocybin, MDMA analogs, LSD) are still in phase 2 or 3, with filings not expected until 2026 or later, and that recent regulatory actions have signaled higher evidentiary standards and a cautious regulatory stance.

However, nearly all experts note that the current political climate is unusually conducive to regulatory action: there is significant bipartisan advocacy, explicit statements by the new FDA and HHS leadership about accelerating psychedelic reviews, and increased public, investor, and veteran advocacy pressure. Several experts observe that an NDA/EUA filing does not need to be accepted—only filed—for the question to resolve Yes, and that the DEA could act to reschedule a psychedelic outside of the FDA's typical timeline, especially under political pressure. Despite this, most experts stress the lack of public evidence for any imminent NDA/EUA filing or formal DEA rescheduling for psychedelics as of mid-October 2025, and the general inertia of regulatory processes despite favorable signals.

Numerical probabilities among the experts mostly cluster in the 22–42% range, with single extremely low outliers (9% and 12%) from perspectives emphasizing regulatory inertia and the direct aftermath of the FDA rejection. The modal forecast is around 30–38%. The most commonly cited plausible Yes scenarios are either a strategic or symbolic NDA/EUA filing by a company hoping to capitalize on the favorable political climate or a politically driven DEA rescheduling (for MDMA or psilocybin), possibly as a gesture in response to advocacy rather than based on newly matured clinical data.

In summary: The expert consensus is that, while the probability of a regulatory next step for psychedelic medical approval in the US in 2025 is higher than in previous years due to unprecedented political and regulatory momentum, the lack of mature pivotal data and public announcements from sponsors means that the status quo is still more likely. Most experts forecast a probability of 30–40% for a qualifying NDA, EUA, or DEA rescheduling action before January 1, 2026, with the chance of inaction remaining greater than a coin flip.
